snippet.textDisplay: Two observations: 1. Surely the multiverse would get so great a making black holes that they should predominate in the vast majority of universes?   2. If we are inside a black hole somewhere, then our whole universe may be subject to cataclysmic destruction via possible events, such as merging with another singularity.

snippet.textDisplay: When thinking of blackholes especially their ability to warp spacetime  into (almost) infinity I miss a thing concerning mass and denisty. Here is what I think. Stellar blackholes are a product of a dead stars (more-less their inner core). Lets say that the mass of the star was 1 before its collapse into a blackhole. Its obvious that the mass of the blackhole created of that star must be less then 1. So here is the question: why does a blackhole warp spacetime more then a star of which that blackhole was created? Why the gravity of blackhole is so much larger then the gravity of the star which it originated form? If its not the mass which warps that spacetime so is it the denisty? If so, why there is no density in Newtons equetions? What if only density not mass is only couse of the gravitational interaction? Mayby the gravity itself is not a fundamental force, but similar to temperature (being and average movement of particles) is a kind of average "thing"  somehowe connected to the density?

snippet.textDisplay:
(first 10 seconds of the video, I haven't watched it all yet but ive freaked out with excitement lol) I came up with an idea 6 months ago that the end of the Universe (many trillions & trillions of years from now) will be when all that's left is black holes, and they eventually all come together to form one giant hyper black hole, at the moment that every last single piece of energy & light that ever existed falls in and becomes it.... the clock resets and another big bang happens. I don't have an A-Level or qualification to my name, it just seems like the only logical fate.

In case you're wondering how the universe will retract after expanding for so long, well my theory is that LIGHT itself is the candidate for the so called DARK ENERGY, if light can push a solar sail along and be influenced by gravity then it logically has substance of a sort, that is what I believe also accounts for the missing key of what holds galaxies together, LIGHT ITSELF. After all.... everything IS light in one wave form or another, its just such a simple idea that it has been completely overlooked due to man kinds obsession with over complicating everything. Take away the light, and there is nothing to push the Universe apart any more, so that is when gravity gets hold of things when all that is left is BLack Holes, after all the Universe will one day grow darker and darker, but currently there is still plenty of stuff to form new Stars. But one day even the white dwarfs will grow dim and fade out.

Now, what will cook your noodle is this, the light that has also travelled trillions and trillions of light years across the Universe will also have to be pulled back into the giant Hyper Black hole before the clock can reset, so basically EVERYTHING that EVER existed needs to be pulled in to complete the cycle, but once that happens BOOM! A new Big Bang and a new Universe with possible and identical set of laws and timescale, maybe even people? Maybe that accounts for Deja Vu? lol.... we are talking some unimaginable time scales here, but it makes perfect sense and seems the only logical fate for OUR Laws of Physics.
I do love thinking! Yet they always tell me its unhealthy to think too much... nonsense haha!

snippet.textDisplay: Evolution is a myth. That would imply that information is being added to our DNA as time goes on. Where is this new information coming from? In fact, we are losing information as time goes on generation after generation. So, if I throw people off of cliff for a million years are they going to sprout wings because they need to survive? The answer is a resounding no. I’m afraid I would have just killed a bunch people.

snippet.textDisplay:
It seems to me that there is alot of 'like' speculation of the origin of the fine structure constant, and other constants. The fundamental problem is that we do not have a solid understanding of spacetime. I think that experiments here on Earth demonstrate that gravitational constant is not as constant as physicist seem to posit. It is possible that under extreme circumstances the variation might even be greater. The fine structure of spacetime, which Smolin and Ravoli have worked on via LQG, are dependent on a set of dynamic structures that were propagated somehow from the early universe. [Noting that Ravoli implies that time is an illusion and Smolin implies Time is 'real' and Space is an illusion . . . . .so even they disagree about the fundamentals of how loop quantum gravity works]
 A bigger problem for these speculations is that spacetime is 'dynamical' and in a sense deterministic. The properties of spacetime that we experience are essentially 'averaging out' of a very large number of interactions at the quantum scale of fields being propagated from all directions at the speed of light. Where did these fields originate and why is there a certain 'vacuum space' density of them? If we can answer these questions about why are universe has a certain gravitational constant in a certain place, then maybe we can understand some metric of infinite energy density that formed our universe.

In the case of loop quantum gravity, they suggest that the universe did not start as a singularity (obviously a spin network cannot work with a singe mode), thus energy density was finite over a poly-dimensional network. The origin and propagation of the network during inflation (how inflation terminates) communicates information about constants to the expanding universe.
I should also make a point about Smolin; he does not posit that quantum mechanics is not only incomplete . . .he claims its' broken. If you take his critique about QM as fact, then it suggests that there is an underlying level physics to the universe . . . possibly tied up in how 'quantum gravity works' or even more basal. If one considers a network theory of the fundemental particles. Namely he claims that the Schrodinger equation whose value when squared predicts the probability of a particles characteristics is more or less akin to a carpenter approximating an orthogonal lines by always extrapolating from 3 - 4 - 5 triangles when one could the use Pythagorean therom on any point on a line with a third point.

The fundamental problem is that we do not have a solid understanding of spacetime.  I think that experiments here on  Earth demonstrate that gravitational constant is not as constant as physicist seem to posit. It is possible that under extreme circumstances the variation might even be greater. The fine structure of spacetime, which Smolin and Ravoli have worked on via LQG,  are dependent on a set of dynamic structures that were propagated somehow from the early universe. [Noting that Ravoli implies that time is an illusion and Smolin implies Time is 'real' and Space is an illusion  . . . . .so even they disagree about the fundamentals of how loop quantum gravity works] 
 A bigger problem for these speculations  is that spacetime is 'dynamical' and in a sense deterministic. The properties of spacetime that we experience are essentially 'averaging out' of a very large number of interactions at the quantum scale of fields being propagated from all directions at the speed of light. Where did these fields originate and why is there a certain 'vacuum space' density of them? If we can answer these questions about why are universe has a certain gravitational constant in a certain place, then maybe we can understand some metric of infinite energy density that formed our universe. 

   In the case of loop quantum gravity, they suggest that the universe did not start as a singularity (obviously a spin network cannot work with a singe mode), thus energy density was finite over a poly-dimensional network. The origin and propagation of the network during inflation (how inflation terminates) communicates information about constants to the expanding universe.
    I should also make a point about Smolin; he does not posit that quantum mechanics is not only incomplete . . .he claims its' broken.  If you take his critique about QM as fact, then it suggests that there is an underlying level physics to the universe . . . possibly tied up in how 'quantum gravity works' or even more basal. snippet.textDisplay:
Seems straight forward to me. Most of these theories are overthought. ;)

Black holes are simply a singularity born of universal matter, compressed by its own mass and gravity. The more matter you pack in, the larger and more dense it becomes.
There's no reason why galactic and solar black holes can't merge (as they are just space objects), except the passage of time and enough gravitational force to bring everything in the universe back to a single point. The result of this unfathomable gathering of so much 'matter' is a big bang.
snippet.textOriginal:
Seems straight forward to me. Most of these theories are overthought. ;)

Black holes are simply a singularity born of universal matter, compressed by its own mass and gravity. The more matter you pack in, the larger and more dense it becomes.  
There's no reason why galactic and solar black holes can't merge (as they are just space objects), except the passage of time and enough gravitational force to bring everything in the universe back to a single point. The result of this unfathomable gathering of so much 'matter' is a big bang.

snippet.textDisplay:
Biological evolution requires three components:
1) inheritability (by means of DNA)
2) variability (by means of mutation, and later sexual recombination)
3) selection (by means of competing for limited resources)

This framework has the first two for cosmological evolution, but the latter is quite different. There is no death, and no common resources to compete for, only an abstract numbers game for being the most common universe type across the meta-cosmos.

But in the end, I guess that's similar enough to make the connection.
snippet.textOriginal:
Biological evolution requires three components:
1) inheritability (by means of DNA)
2) variability (by means of mutation, and later sexual recombination)
3) selection (by means of competing for limited resources)

This framework has the first two for cosmological evolution, but the latter is quite different. There is no death, and no common resources to compete for, only an abstract numbers game for being the most common universe type across the meta-cosmos.

But in the end, I guess that's similar enough to make the connection.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ok... so now we're on to talking about hypothetical possibilities about unconfirmed effects of currently unknown natural processes..... Can someone please tell me WHY THE FUCK isn't there more about the "Electric Universe" model that has assloads of more evidence, tested experiments, published papers, and has to potential to answer tons of OBSERVED effects without current explanations on a much more PRACTICAL level.



All I'm saying is, with time, effort, resources, funding, etc that goes into thinking about/testing/etc Cosmological Natural Selection of Universe Creating Black Holes that also Change the Cosmological Constants with each iteration but not strictly randomly, in a "genetic" similar style..... We should be able to do far more on the Electromagnetic Connections, interactions, effects, etc than we currently do.... Hell, Lighting is still not understood.... WTF!?!? But I'm supposed to believe that since the Universe as a whole has an overall neutral charge, that the electromagnetic force plays little to no role on the galactic, intergalactic, and universal scales???? A car battery has an overall neutral charge, but it's the charge separation that generates the current, and hence why your car can start. Why cannot a similar, albeit more complex, concept be applied on intergalactic scales??? Are we just going to ignore Halton Arps work??? Hannes Alfvén work on plasma???


Instead we're going to talk about hypothetical possibilities about unconfirmed effects of currently unknown natural processes....... REALLY???



Can ANYONE explain to me WHY!!!!
snippet.textOriginal:
Ok... so now we're on to talking about hypothetical possibilities about unconfirmed effects of currently unknown natural processes..... Can someone please tell me *WHY THE FUCK* isn't there more about the "Electric Universe" model that has assloads of more evidence, tested experiments, published papers, and has to potential to answer tons of *OBSERVED* effects without current explanations on a much more *PRACTICAL* level. 



All I'm saying is, with time, effort, resources, funding, etc that goes into thinking about/testing/etc Cosmological Natural Selection of Universe Creating Black Holes that *also* Change the Cosmological Constants with each iteration but not strictly randomly, in a "genetic" similar style..... We should be able to do far more on the Electromagnetic Connections, interactions, effects, etc than we currently do.... Hell, Lighting is still not understood.... WTF!?!? But I'm supposed to believe that since the Universe as a whole has an *overall* neutral charge, that the electromagnetic force plays little to no role on the galactic, intergalactic, and universal scales???? A car battery has an overall neutral charge, but it's the charge separation that generates the current, and hence why your car can start. Why cannot a similar, albeit more complex, concept be applied on intergalactic scales??? Are we just going to ignore Halton Arps work??? Hannes Alfvén work on plasma???


Instead we're going to talk about hypothetical possibilities about unconfirmed effects of currently unknown natural processes....... REALLY??? 



Can *ANYONE* explain to me *WHY!!!!*

snippet.textDisplay: Dowd says "We know that the fantastic complexity of living organisms is an inevitable consequence of evolution by natural selection." Uh no.....That is a common misconception. Natural selection often times leads to more simplistic biological systems. See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_biological_complexity

snippet.textDisplay: I was talking about this with my brother a few years ago. I'd considered that every 'local' black hole singularity was connected to a single common point in space time. It struck me as funny that each black hole would be like an 'eye' on a potato, with the peel representing space time. When the contents of the 'potato' reached 'critical mass', a new big bang would happen.
snippet.textOriginal: I was talking about this with my brother a few years ago. I'd considered that every 'local' black hole singularity was connected to a single common point in space time. It struck me as funny that each black hole would be like an 'eye' on a potato, with the peel representing space time. When the contents of the 'potato' reached 'critical mass', a new big bang would happen.

snippet.textDisplay: The anthropic principle doesn't make sense, not beyond its weakest form, because we don't know whether there are exotic forms of intelligence that we wouldn't recognize even if we touched them. We are bound to be anthropocentric in these kinds of speculations, so we shouldn't take them too seriously. Lee Smolin's argument is fascinating because it explains why the universe is likely to allow our form of life to exist. It doesn't implicitly assume that our  form of intelligence  is the only possible in any kind of possible universe.  Field fluctuations in a chunk of space of a universe without mass, might be wondering why they exist.
snippet.textOriginal: The anthropic principle doesn't make sense, not beyond its weakest form, because we don't know whether there are exotic forms of intelligence that we wouldn't recognize even if we touched them. We are bound to be anthropocentric in these kinds of speculations, so we shouldn't take them too seriously. Lee Smolin's argument is fascinating because it explains why the universe is likely to allow our form of life to exist. It doesn't implicitly assume that our  form of intelligence  is the only possible in any kind of possible universe.  Field fluctuations in a chunk of space of a universe without mass, might be wondering why they exist.

We should be blowing more shit up, because 'saving the Earth or universe' will halt its evolutionary growth.
Life was introduced to throw a needed spanner in the works to speed things up, once this is accomplished then the bacteria of life can be eliminated from the natural Cosmic cycle. We could start by blowing up Pluto thus stopping all the debates on this useless planet.

Future beings: Imagine life in the past wanted to SAVE the planet, and the reality was we needed to fuk it up.

Thus reeking havoc everywhere and finally eliminating the awkward then unneeded process of the waste of life.

snippet.textDisplay: Singularities have no dimensional component, thus undefined temporal component, making it possible that all singularities are the same singularity. Lacking space-time, cause and effect are undefined as well, thus the universe created by a singularity in this universe could very well be this universe; Infinitely recursive origination. Further, dark and light matter could simply be the same matter; A mirror of itself, existing as both cause and effect simultaneously. That would better fit with quantum entanglement and quantum field theory, while rendering cosmological natural selection erroneous. Just a thought.
snippet.textOriginal: Singularities have no dimensional component, thus undefined temporal component, making it possible that *all* singularities are the *same* singularity. Lacking space-time, cause and effect are undefined as well, thus the universe created by a singularity in this universe could very well *be* this universe; Infinitely recursive origination. Further, dark and light matter could simply be the *same* matter; A mirror of itself, existing as both cause *and* effect simultaneously. That would better fit with quantum entanglement and quantum field theory, while rendering cosmological natural selection erroneous. Just a thought.

snippet.textDisplay:
So I"m surely not the only one to think so but:
If (one of) life's products is intelligent life and intelligent life is "blessed" with curiosity, which (provided a long enough period of time) will lead to intelligent life trying (and eventually succeeding) to create black holes themselves (be it for experimental reasons or for other purposes)... Wouldn't that mean that "fine-tuned for the existence of life" and "fine-tuned for the existence of black holes" are if not the same, then at least correlated?..

snippet.textDisplay: Black holes possess just a tiny portion of the entire universe's mass/energy. Hence every child universe should have a much lower initial mass. Continue that process  to the infinity and suddenly there'll be no mass available to form any black holes and therefore new universes. I'm not a physicist so really struggling to understand if and where I'm wrong with this logic?

snippet.textDisplay: To say that the fundamental particles are just right for life is untrue. Life evolved around the fundamental particles and not the other way around. snippet.textDisplay:
Does our universe exist in a Black hole … that is in our universe … is our universe in every black hole in our universe …

Visualize. it like this. You are standing in the entry hall of a house. Behind you is the front door of the house, it has no door knob and cannot be opened. you wander around the house and there are several doors, with knobs You go through one of these doors and close it behind you noticing that the door does not have a knob on the inside. You are back in the entry hall. You try other doors with the same result.

Now are you in a house, in a house, in a house or the same house folded in upon itself?
snippet.textOriginal:
Does our universe exist in a Black hole … that is in our universe …  is our universe in every black hole in our universe …

Visualize. it like this. You are standing in the entry hall of a house. Behind you is the front door of the house, it has no door knob and cannot be opened. you wander around the house and there are several doors, with knobs  You go through one of these doors and close it behind you noticing that the door does not have a knob on the inside. You are back in the entry hall. You try other doors with the same result.

Now are you in a house, in a house, in a house or the same house folded in upon itself?

snippet.textDisplay:
what if the theory turn out to be half true and black holes need um.. a catalyst (white hole) to create a universe.
those white holes will come from an anti-universe
this would explain why the baby universe will have different cosmological constant than his parent because he has two, so constants average out.
it can also explain dark matter as our universe's fiancé sticking around until they hit puberty and have their 'big bang'; however it raises the question: should we worry about a cosmic menstruation
